channel.title: How do you know what to look for?
channel.description: Ok, so you have an updater base, ready to start making a simple updater. You want to search for the version number. You got it. Next, you want to search for... lets say... character's getAnimation. How do you know what field to look for in order to start making a pattern?[br][br][size=1]Posted on: March 08, 2008, 02:18:23 PM[/size][hr]In other words, how do you know what to look for?

item.title: How do you know what to look for?
item.dc:creator: @semaphore semaphore
item.description:
@semaphore wrote:

[quote=“yakman, post:65, topic:187422”]speaking of your sig…
why do you have a c++ snippet in a forum which is mostly java?[/quote]

mostly != all

It is a technical joke.

yakman:

also, your method, DontUnderstand(), in most c++ stuff iv seen, the first word is lowercase, but the rest are uppercase, so like dontUnderstand() would follow this convention

Simply wrong. First, I think you were looking for the word camel-case. Second, your experience must be incredibly limited because for years first letter capitalization was standard at many places I have worked.

yakman:

also with RTFM(), thats an order isnt it? you tell someone to RTFM, so why does it appear to return a boolean? is it RTFM and return true if successful? or is it “did this person RTFM”, in that case, it should be hasRTFM() or something.

Unless it is to be read as read in past-tense; in which case it would be a property on the object pointed to by the pointer to you. The whole point was to check if you had done all the things in the expression part of the if statement. It wouldn’t make sense if the code were calling a function "order"ing you to do it. It simply checks to see if you have.

[quote=“yakman, post:65, topic:187422”]also, im not so sure about this in c++, but in java, everyone tries to write the full name of everything, they write BufferedReader so its clearer to remember then BufferReader or BufReader, and stuff ends up being very long, like StringIndexOutOfBoundsException,
so with this logic, it shouldnt be RTFM() but readTheFuckingManual()[/quote]

If you aren’t sure, why respond?

yakman:

:o

:o

leave my sig the hell alone.

Read full topic
item.source: How do you know what to look for?

item.title: How do you know what to look for?
item.dc:creator: @yakman yakman
item.description:
@yakman wrote:

semaphore:

leave my sig the hell alone.

speaking of your sig…
why do you have a c++ snippet in a forum which is mostly java?

also, your method, DontUnderstand(), in most c++ stuff iv seen, the first word is lowercase, but the rest are uppercase, so like dontUnderstand() would follow this convention

also with RTFM(), thats an order isnt it? you tell someone to RTFM, so why does it appear to return a boolean? is it RTFM and return true if successful? or is it “did this person RTFM”, in that case, it should be hasRTFM() or something.

also, im not so sure about this in c++, but in java, everyone tries to write the full name of everything, they write BufferedReader so its clearer to remember then BufferReader or BufReader, and stuff ends up being very long, like StringIndexOutOfBoundsException,
so with this logic, it shouldnt be RTFM() but readTheFuckingManual()

:o

Read full topic
item.source: How do you know what to look for?

item.title: How do you know what to look for?
item.dc:creator: @solarwind solarwind
item.description:
@solarwind wrote:

[quote=“semaphore, post:63, topic:187422”]Honestly, your best course of action, since you seem to have the determination to stick with it, is to look at the currently available code to reverse the client. Look at what it does. Pay close attention to the patterns it looks for. Study them… the reverser that is currently available is not that far off. Try your best to figure out and understand what exactly the reverser is doing. Once you have a firm grasp of the transformations that must be reversed in order to view the client in a logical form, try making your own. In a nutshell, all a reverser is doing is finding patterns of bytecode and applying transformations to them; in hopes that these transformations will lead to re-compilable code produced by jad or jode.

Give yourself alot of time. Personally, I wouldn’t depend on anyone to give you any code… not that that is a bad thing…

One of the main reasons, in my opinion, that no one shares anything is because this game is very simple to reverse. It is quite easy to create a working bot from scratch. What isn’t trivial is finding every client-side trap to catch bots. I think this is the information that takes the most time to glean and hence is the most closely guarded.

As for delete, parenthesis are fine. It’s a clarification/habit thing; leave my sig the hell alone. :)[/quote]
Thanks for that. The most valuable advice I got so far is to decompile a client, stick it in an IDE and refactor when you find stuff. So far, I took the output from Ollie and Qauters and refactored it like that to learn how certain things are done. That way, I was able to form patterns for fields on my own.

I also made a deobfuscator shell. Time to finish it. Thanks semaphore!

Read full topic
item.source: How do you know what to look for?

item.title: How do you know what to look for?
item.dc:creator: @semaphore semaphore
item.description:
@semaphore wrote:

Honestly, your best course of action, since you seem to have the determination to stick with it, is to look at the currently available code to reverse the client. Look at what it does. Pay close attention to the patterns it looks for. Study them… the reverser that is currently available is not that far off. Try your best to figure out and understand what exactly the reverser is doing. Once you have a firm grasp of the transformations that must be reversed in order to view the client in a logical form, try making your own. In a nutshell, all a reverser is doing is finding patterns of bytecode and applying transformations to them; in hopes that these transformations will lead to re-compilable code produced by jad or jode.

Give yourself alot of time. Personally, I wouldn’t depend on anyone to give you any code… not that that is a bad thing…

One of the main reasons, in my opinion, that no one shares anything is because this game is very simple to reverse. It is quite easy to create a working bot from scratch. What isn’t trivial is finding every client-side trap to catch bots. I think this is the information that takes the most time to glean and hence is the most closely guarded.

As for delete, parenthesis are fine. It’s a clarification/habit thing; leave my sig the hell alone.

Read full topic

item.title: How do you know what to look for?
item.dc:creator: @solarwind solarwind
item.description:
@solarwind wrote:

[quote=“frank_, post:55, topic:187422”][quote author=solarwind link=topic=250036.msg2105026#msg2105026 date=1205359520]
Why is everyone so stingy in posting source code around here?
[/quote]
because it gets leeched, and you wouldnt bother to learn how it works

and because we dont want to make it easier for jagex to break

and because we are faggots[/quote]

  1. Some people leech, but those are idiots and wouldn’t know what to do with a deob client anyway. And I would learn how it works, TRUST me…
  2. Good point.
  3. Not everyone, only certain people…
Speljohan:

Popcorn’s Deobber works fine if you don’t use JAD.

Hmm, what should I use then? JODE? I thought JODE has a tendency to crash at certain instruction sequences…

Read full topic

either ask someone nicely for a deob, or learn what is being done and write your own deobfuscator

i would say myself, but i havent looked at my deobber for over 4 months and i am pretty sure i broke it, ooooor anyone that seems to know what they are talking about
[/quote]
Frank, can you please send me your deobfuscator, kind sir?[/quote]
even if it worked, no. if it worked, i would give you a deobbed client, though
